items.title: Streamlining CI/CD process with AWS and Bitbucket Pipelines: A Step-by-Step Guide
items.author: William SJ
items.description:
TL;DR: This tutorial is also available in video format. Click here to watchÂ it.

In todayâ€™s fast-paced software world, automation is your best friend. Our guide is your ticket to automating how you deploy your applications and improving your development process.

By combining the powers of AWS CodeDeploy and Bitbucket Pipelines, weâ€™ll show you how to make continuous integration and deployment a piece ofÂ cake.

This guide will be your trusty companion as we walk you through setting up a strong deployment system. Weâ€™ll help you blend AWS and Bitbucket seamlessly to make your development process smoother and more efficient than everÂ before.

In this tutorial, Iâ€™ll be using ASP.NET Core Project to do CI/CD, please adjust accordingly to your needs. You can get the tutorial repository fromÂ here.

Part 1: AWSÂ Setup

1.1 Create IAMÂ Group

  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open the IAM console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/iam/.
  2. In the navigation pane, click User Groups and then click Create NewÂ Group.
  3. In the Group Name box, type the group's name (bit_CodeDeployRole).
  4. In the list of policies, select the check box for Policy:
    * AmazonS3FullAccess
    * AWSCodeDeployFullAccess
  5. Click CreateÂ Group.

1.2 Create IAMÂ User

  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open the IAM console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/iam/.
  2. In the navigation pane, click Users and then click AddÂ User.
  3. Type the user name (CodeDeployUser) for the newÂ user.
  4. Donâ€™t tick â€œProvide user access to the AWS Management Consoleâ€.
  5. On the Set permissions page, select Add user to group for permission options.
  6. Choose the group that youâ€™ve created in the previous step (bit_CodeDeployRole).

1.2.1 Generate AccessÂ Keys

  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open the IAM console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/iam/.
  2. In the navigation pane, clickÂ Users.
  3. Click on the username that you want to create access keysÂ for.
  4. Click on the Security Credentials tab.
  5. Under Access Keys, click Create AccessÂ keys
  6. Select the use case, fill in the description, and click Create accessÂ key
  7. Click DownloadÂ .csv file to save your accessÂ key.
You cannot view the access keys after you leave thisÂ page.

1.3 Configure IAMÂ Role

  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open the IAM console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/iam/.
  2. In the navigation pane, click Roles and then click CreateÂ Role.
  3. Choose AWS service for Trusted entityÂ type.
  4. Choose EC2 for the useÂ case.
  5. Click Next.
  6. In the list of policies, select the check box for Policy:
    * AmazonS3FullAccess
    * AWSCodeDeployRole
    * AmazonEC2FullAccess
    * AmazonSSMFullAccess
  7. Enter role name (AWSCodeDeployRole).
  8. Click CreateÂ Role.
  9. On the Roles page, click on the role that you justÂ created.
  10. Click the Trust Relationship tab.
  11. Click Edit TrustÂ Policy.
  12. Click Add Principal, choose AWS service, and fill codedeploy.ap-southeast-1.amazonaws.com for ARN (Change region accordingly)
  13. Click Save.

2.1 Create an AWS S3Â Bucket

  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open the Amazon S3 console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/s3/.
  2. Click CreateÂ Bucket.
  3. Type a unique name for your new bucket in the Bucket name field. Ex: bitbucket-codedeploy-deployment.
  4. For Region, choose Asia Pacific (Singapore) ap-southeast-1 as the region where you want the bucket toÂ reside.
  5. Choose ACLs Enabled, and Bucket Owner preferred as the BucketÂ option.
  6. Click CreateÂ Bucket.

3.1 Set Up an AWS EC2Â Instance

  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open the Amazon EC2 console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/ec2/.
  2. Click Launch Instance.
  3. Fill in the name for EC2 Instance. Ex: CodeDeployDirect
  4. Choose the required OS Images. Iâ€™m using Microsoft Windows Server 2022 Base as Iâ€™m tryingÂ this.
  5. Click Create a new key pair if you donâ€™t have any key pair. Remember to save theÂ .pem file, youâ€™ll need to access this instance.
  6. Under Network Settings, tick Allow RDP Traffic from Anywhere, Allow HTTP Traffic from Anywhere, Allow HTTPS Traffic from Anywhere.
  7. Under Advanced Options, choose the role that weâ€™ve created for this (AWSCodeDeployRole) for the IAM InstanceÂ Profile.
  8. Click Launch Instance.

3.1.1 Connect toÂ Instance

  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open the Amazon EC2 console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/ec2/.
  2. In the navigation pane, choose Instances.
  3. Click on the instance that you justÂ created.
  4. Click Connect.
  5. Click the RDP Client tab. Pick Connect using the RDP client.
    Download the Remote Desktop ClientÂ file.
  6. Click Get Password. Youâ€™ll get prompted for the key pairÂ .pem file that weâ€™ve doneÂ before.
  7. Connect to the instance using the RDP ClientÂ file.

3.1.2 InstallÂ IIS

  1. Open up ServerÂ Manager.
  2. In the navigation bar, click Add Roles or Features.
  3. Tick Role-based or feature-based installation.
  4. For Server selection, just choose the available server.
  5. In the Server Roles, tick the following features:
    * Web Server (IIS)
    * Windows Deployment Services
  6. In the Features, tickÂ .NET 3.5 andÂ .NETÂ 4.8.
  7. Then just click Next, and let itÂ install.
  8. If you encounter errors, most probably youâ€™ll need to install NET
    Core Hosting Bundle    Â first.

3.1.3 Install System ManagerÂ Agent

  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open this https://console.aws.amazon.com/systems-manager/fleet-manager/dhmc.
  2. Enable Default Host Management Configuration.
  3. Choose the AWSSystemsManagerDefaultEC2InstanceManagementRole role (create it if you donâ€™t haveÂ one).
  4. This will allow our instances to show up in the Fleet Manager as managed nodes. You should be able to see your instance showed up in FleetÂ Manager.
  5. Connect to the instance.
  6. Install SSM Agent. Follow this instructions.
  7. Run these commands on Powershell.
[System.Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol = 'TLS12'
$progressPreference = 'silentlyContinue'
Invoke-WebRequest `
    https://s3.amazonaws.com/ec2-downloads-windows/SSMAgent/latest/windows_amd64/AmazonSSMAgentSetup.exe `
    -OutFile $env:USERPROFILE\Desktop\SSMAgent_latest.exe

Start-Process `
    -FilePath $env:USERPROFILE\Desktop\SSMAgent_latest.exe `
    -ArgumentList "/S"

rm -Force $env:USERPROFILE\Desktop\SSMAgent_latest.exe

Restart-Service AmazonSSMAgent

3.1.4 Install CodeDeploy Agent

  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open this https://console.aws.amazon.com/systems-manager/distributor
  2. Choose AWSCodeDeployAgent and click Install oneÂ time.
  3. Use default options, except Target Selection.
    Chooses instances manually, you should be able to choose your instance.
  4. Click Run.
  5. Verify that the service is running on the instance by running thisÂ command.
powershell.exe -Command Get-Service -Name codedeployagent

4.1 Create an AWS CodeDeploy Application

  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open the CodeDeploy Application console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/codesuite/codedeploy/applications.
  2. Click Create Application.
  3. Fill in the Application Name (e.g.: directcodedeploy) and choose EC2/On-premises as the Compute Platform.
  4. Under Deployment Groups, click Create Deployment Group.
  5. Fill necessary fields:
    * Deployment Group: DG1 (Anything)
    * Service Role: AWSCodeDeployRole
    * Deployment Type: In-place
    * Environment Configuration:
    - Tick Amazon EC2 instances
    -     Fill in the Name for Key
    - Choose the instance name in the Value field. Ex: CodeDeployDirect
    - Should show 1 matching instance.
    * Deployment Settings: CodeDeployDefault.OneAtATime
    * Load Balancer: Disabled
  6. Click Create Deployment Group.

Part 2: Bitbucket Configuration

1. Enable Pipelines

  1. Sign in to the Bitbucket and navigate to your repository.
  2. On the sidebar, navigate to Repository Settings.
  3. Under the Pipelines section, click Settings.
  4. Enable Pipelines.

2. Create bitbucket-pipelines.yml in the root folder of theÂ project

The example below is for the ASP NET Core 6 Web Application.
Please update accordingly.

image: mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/sdk:6.0
pipelines:
 default:
  - step:
    name: Build and Test
    caches:
     - dotnetcore
    script:
     - dotnet restore
     - dotnet build
     - dotnet test
  - step:
    name: Publish and Deploy
    deployment: staging
    script:
     - apt-get update && apt-get install zip -y
     - dotnet publish -c Release -o ./publish
     - cp appspec.yml ./publish/appspec.yml
     - cp before-iis-install-stop.bat ./publish/before-iis-install-stop.bat
     - cp after-iis-install-start.bat ./publish/after-iis-install-start.bat
     - cd ./publish
     - zip -r WebApp.zip .
     - pipe: atlassian/aws-code-deploy:0.2.5
      variables:
       AWS_DEFAULT_REGION: $AWS_DEFAULT_REGION
       AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID: $AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID
       AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY: $AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY
       APPLICATION_NAME: $APPLICATION_NAME
       S3_BUCKET: $S3_BUCKET
       COMMAND: "upload"
       ZIP_FILE: "WebApp.zip"
       VERSION_LABEL: "web-app-1.0.0"
     - pipe: atlassian/aws-code-deploy:0.2.5
      variables:
       AWS_DEFAULT_REGION: $AWS_DEFAULT_REGION
       AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID: $AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID
       AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY: $AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY
       APPLICATION_NAME: $APPLICATION_NAME
       DEPLOYMENT_GROUP: $DEPLOYMENT_GROUP
       S3_BUCKET: $S3_BUCKET
       COMMAND: "deploy"
       WAIT: "true"
       VERSION_LABEL: "web-app-1.0.0"
       IGNORE_APPLICATION_STOP_FAILURES: "true"
       FILE_EXISTS_BEHAVIOR: "OVERWRITE"
       DEBUG: "true"
    artifacts:
     - dist/**

3. Create appspec.yml, before-iis-install-stop.bat, and after-iis-install-start.bat in the root folder of theÂ project

appspec.yml is to tell AWS CodeDeploy what to do in the deployment process.
before-iis-install-stop.bat will stop IIS before overwriting the files to prevent IIS from still accessing the web files.
after-iis-install-start.bat will start IIS after copying the webÂ files.

4. Add Repository Variables

  1. Sign in to the Bitbucket and navigate to your repository.
  2. On the sidebar, navigate to Repository Settings.
  3. Under the Pipelines section, click Repository Variables.
  4. These are required variables in the bitbucket-pipelines.yml:
    * AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID
    * AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY
    * AWS_DEFAULT_REGION
    * S3_BUCKET
    * APPLICATION_NAME
    * DEPLOYMENT_GROUP

By following these detailed steps, you can establish a powerful and automated deployment pipeline, ensuring the smooth delivery of your applications from Bitbucket to AWS services. Say goodbye to manual deployment headaches and embrace the future of streamlined development workflows.

Happy coding and deploying!

items.title: Minimalism, Hustle Culture, where does it all goes?
items.author: William SJ
items.description:
Minimalism, Hustle Culture, Where does it AllÂ Goes?

Minimalism, Hustle Culture, Maximalism, and all the new ideologies that emerged in the last fewÂ years.

Where does it all goesÂ now?

Iâ€™m sure youâ€™ve heard one of these terms that I spoke earlier. (Except you are not following the news at all. Good for you thenÂ ğŸ™Œ)

Lemme try to tell you what does these new termsÂ mean.

Minimalism is an ideology that values keeping important things in your life and ditching the rest. It was popularized by The Minimalist and Marie Kondo in her â€œKonmariâ€ method. (You know, the â€œSparking Joyâ€ one, yep that oneÂ ğŸ˜)

Hustle Culture as itsâ€™ name implies, a culture that pushes hard work, pushing yourself beyond your limits to achieve capitalist goals, such as wealth, prosperity, and success as fast as possible.

This was popularized by Gary Vaynerchuk or as known as GaryVee, an entrepreneur, social media influencer, and also aÂ writer.

GaryVee is a hardcore hustler that likes to work a lot of hours. He has several businesses, and multiple social media platforms, which he published contentsÂ daily.

If you have someone that screaming â€œHUSTLE! HUSTLE! HUSTLE!â€, thatâ€™s probably GaryVee is coming for you. (Iâ€™m jokingÂ okay)

And then the Maximalism, itâ€™s the opposite of Minimalism, an ideology that sees beauty of excess in life. This came from the reaction of the bunch of Minimalism contents outÂ there.

Phew, Iâ€™ve covered the quick background of eachÂ term.

The questionÂ is,

Where does it allÂ goes?

Not only Minimalism, Hustle Culture, Maximalism, but also all the new terms that are popping out of nowhere these few yearsÂ back.

First of all, thereâ€™s nothing wrong on sticking with the philosophy if itâ€™s applicable in your life and itâ€™s working. The annoying part is, people like to force their choice of philosophy to otherÂ person.

Second of all, itâ€™s okay to not following each new trends thatâ€™s popularized by influencers.

You doÂ you.

The reason that these trends has come to an end, itâ€™s because people are realizing that itâ€™s just a â€œtrendâ€, and itâ€™s not for them. People are moving on to the next shinyÂ thing.

So, the new trends will keep popping out, thatâ€™s forÂ sure.

Itâ€™s the matter of you, the one that decides is this suitable forÂ you.

I think different person has a different way of livingÂ too.

One thing that I like to highlight is,

Everybody needs to keep improving their own life. That would be a great foundation to achieve a betterÂ life.

P.S Iâ€™mÂ back!

Itâ€™s been quite a long time since I write an article. Iâ€™m quite busy with my college (Hurray, itâ€™s done!) andÂ work.

Hope you guys are doing well over there asÂ well!

Please leave a clap if it resonates with youÂ ğŸ˜Š.

Thanks a lot for taking the time readingÂ this.

Have a greatÂ day!

items.title: These Are 3 Things That Will Boost Your Finance in Your 20s.
items.author: William SJ
items.description:
Have you ever wondered how to grow your money faster? How to become rich like yourÂ peers?

Buying stocks? or evenÂ Crypto?

Start a business?

Well, yeah maybe. I said maybe because even if you followed their paths, it does not mean you will get what they got asÂ well.

Then, whatâ€™s the point of this post? ImmaÂ leaves.

WAIT! I promised you that I will tell you the sure way to become wealthy (notÂ rich).

Okay, good? Letâ€™sÂ start.

1. Check your Financial Health

If you want to grow your money faster, youâ€™ll need to know your current financial health.

  • Do you have an income? (You need to have an income to grow money, or else what toÂ grow?)
  • Do you have any debts? (Preferably donâ€™t have any debts, but we donâ€™t know everyoneâ€™s situation right?)
  • Is it higher than your income? (Well, if itâ€™s higher, then it means you cannot pay your ownÂ debt.)
  • Do you save every month? (Itâ€™s okay if itâ€™s not that much, 10$ is better thanÂ none)

These are a few questions you need to ask yourself and answer honestly. Do all the calculations, even if itâ€™sÂ scary.

If you pass all the questions, congrats!

At least, you can take care of your ownÂ ass.

2. Track and allocate.

Second of all, do you track your expenses? Well if you donâ€™t, I suggest you doÂ so.

By tracking your expenses, you will know how much you spent each month onÂ average.

But, Iâ€™m forgetful, how can I track every singleÂ expense.

Well, maybe you can go the second route. Allocate your monthly budgeting.

There are two routes to chooseÂ from:

  • Lazy way:

If you hate doing tedious things like spreadsheets and you have two debit cards, you can allocate a monthly allowance on one card, and use the other one forÂ savings.

Itâ€™s easier this way, and it allows you to spend whatever you want as long as you still got the money on the card. Keep in mind to never transfer more money from the savingsÂ card.

  • Nice way:

If you are a spreadsheet guru, then I highly recommend you to use spreadsheets on creating monthly budgeting. Itâ€™s easier to track and more flexible.

Either way, if you track and allocate, then you are good toÂ go!

3. Invest

You need to complete previous the two steps before going to the thirdÂ step.

Now we are talking about the real dealÂ here.

Why do we need toÂ invest?

Is it evenÂ safe?

Will we go bankrupt?

We need to invest because savings is not helping us on growing money.Â Period.

Have you ever noticed how things are getting more expensive each year? Thatâ€™s called inflation.

In order to beat inflation, we need to invest and take advantage of compounding interest.

Now, what is compounding interest? Reinvesting the result of our investment to create moreÂ profits.

Wait, before we dive too deep into investing, there are three things you need to doÂ first:

  • Build your emergency funds

What I mean by emergency funds is money that are used in case of unexpected expenses (E.g. hospital costs, you get fired, vehicle reparation, etc).

If you havenâ€™t done the second step, which is Track and Allocate, you wonâ€™t know how much emergency funds you need toÂ have.

The rule of thumb is six to twelve times your monthly expenses.

If you have a family, I suggest going twelveÂ times.

So that means even if you get fired, at least youâ€™ll be able to live for 12Â months.

  • Get an insurance

People will be thankful for insurance that they got only after they got into a problem. Some insurances will cover up to 100% of theÂ costs.

Please consider getting it if you donâ€™t have one. Better be safe than beÂ sorry.

  • Use only coldÂ cash

Cold cash? What isÂ that?

Cold cash is money that is ready toÂ use.

Money that is idling in theÂ bank.

You wouldnâ€™t want to risk your meal allowance for something uncertain.

After youâ€™ve done these points, at least you have a safety net to catch you even if you lost all yourÂ money.

You need to remember that investing by no means is a sure get rich quick tool. Itâ€™s uncertain like how we cannot predict theÂ future.

There are few investing instruments in the world ranging from low profit but stable investments, or high-risk high-return investments.

I suggest that if you are a beginner, learn as much as you can about an instrument that you are interested toÂ buy.

In that way, at least you understand what you buy. Be a smart buyer, donâ€™t be aÂ gambler.

These are a few instruments that IÂ knew:

  • Mutual Funds
  • Obligation
  • Stocks
  • Forex (Foreign Exchange)
  • Cryptocurrencies

Final Notes

These are steps that will help you get wealthier in the longÂ run.

Go for a long marathon, not a shortÂ sprint.

For a quick summary, these are the steps you need toÂ take:

  1. Check Your Financial Health
  2. Track andÂ Allocate
  3. Invest

Learn along the way with your practice.

Donâ€™t be a FOMO (Fear of Missing Out) in the investment world, It will do you noÂ good.

Good luckÂ dude!

items.title: The Advice You Need To Escape â€œTutorial Hellâ€
items.author: William SJ
items.description:
TL;DR You need to get off tutorials and start building something on yourÂ own!

I believe that everybody whoâ€™s reading this has followed or seen a tutorial to do something. When you are doing so, be careful of â€œTutorial Hellâ€.

What the hell is â€œTutorial Hellâ€ youÂ asked?

It is a stage where a beginner tends to depend on tutorials to do things, even simple tasks. So, they will chain a tutorial to another tutorial whenever they want to do something.

Is itÂ bad?

Umm, not really. But, if youâ€™re in this â€œTutorial Hellâ€, youâ€™ll never make something magnificent or sellable stuff, because all you do is copying other peopleâ€™sÂ work.

In this era, where you can basically obtain any kinds of information you want. Absolutely, you can find tutorials for everything.

Even, you can find tutorials for breathing!
Absurd? Yes.
Bad?Â No.

It just what it is now, people put every kind of information on the internet.

Then, why we fell into â€œTutorial Hellâ€?

Because we feel overwhelmed to do something that is unknown to us.
By following a tutorial, we get this feeling of comfort in mind that we will accomplish something, and a tutorial is risk-free.

What I meant by risk-free is you donâ€™t have to go through stress to fix stuff.
Itâ€™s all there for you toÂ follow.

Also, when we finished a tutorial, we get a sense of progression. But in the end, if you only informed how to do something, but never get your hands dirty, how the hell are you gonna master aÂ skill?

When talking about â€œTutorial Hellâ€, we canâ€™t forget â€œImpostor Syndromeâ€, a syndrome that makes you doubt your own skills. So, people loop on tutorials until they feelÂ â€œreadyâ€.

Now, what to doÂ then?

It may sound obvious, but you need to get off tutorials and start building your ownÂ thing.

Youâ€™ll encounter all kinds of problems that didnâ€™t occur when youâ€™re following a tutorial. In that way, youâ€™ll understand better about that specificÂ topic.

Donâ€™t doubt your own skill. How are people gonna trust you even yourself doubt your ownÂ skills?

Itâ€™s okay to make mistakes, myÂ friend.

P.S Iâ€™m not totally out of this â€œTutorial Hellâ€ thingy, but Iâ€™m trying to do my own stuff too. Have a goodÂ day.

items.title: 4 Steps To Cut Down Your Screen Time To 2 Hours
items.author: William SJ
items.description:
Duh, I donâ€™t have enough time. I wished we have 48 hours aÂ day.

No, no we canâ€™t change how many hours does a day has. We can only manage our time nicely and efficiently.

Did you know? The average person spends about 4 hours a day on theirÂ phone.

WHAT? Our phone has been a necessity in our life now. We take it everywhere. We use it to text, call somebody, buy food, keep notes, or evenÂ maps.

The phone has been evolved from just texting and calling devices to multifunctional devices that we useÂ today.

Yep, but the most time consumed things on our phoneÂ is

*let the drumsÂ roll*

Social Media

Yep, let it on Instagram, Facebook, Snapchat, Twitter, YouTube or you sayÂ it.

I used to be like thatÂ too.

I have this app called Digital Wellbeing on my phone (Itâ€™s kind of like ScreenTime onÂ iPhone).

It tracks how many hours you spent on yourÂ phone.

When I opened that app, Boom! 6â€“7 hours averageÂ daily.

Itâ€™s mindblowing right? But it is what itÂ is.

So I thought of fixing thisÂ habit.

I like to watch YouTubeÂ videos.

When I eat, I watch YouTube.
When Iâ€™m bored, I watch YouTube.
When Iâ€™m learning, I watchÂ YouTube.

See, that is where I spent my 6â€“7 hoursÂ on.

So yeah, I saw a video that talks about Digital Minimalism.

A few minutes into the video, I think this is interesting.
And I said to myself, â€œWell, It doesnâ€™t hurt to try itÂ anywayâ€.

So I didÂ it.

So this is what Iâ€™ve learned
Here itÂ is:

First step.
Delete Your SocialÂ Media.

Youâ€™re crazy. You must be calling me that now.
Chill,Â chill.

What I meant by that is you delete your social media apps that you think takes too much of your time but donâ€™t give much value toÂ you.

But if you get values on those social media apps, then go ahead and use them. (Like if you make money fromÂ there).

BUT If you use those apps and you only waste your time there, then delete it. Delete your Facebook, Twitter, Snapchat, Instagram, and even YouTube.
(You only can disable your YouTube app though, well it does the same thing soÂ yeah).

The hardest app for me to delete is YouTube. It takes me a lot of will to delete it. (You saw how often I used YouTube earlier, so you can understand right? or maybeÂ not.)

You deleted all those apps. ThenÂ what?

Second Step.
Put your essential apps on your home screen. So you can use them moreÂ easily.

(Reduce the friction, youÂ know)

If you are a writer, maybe keep your note-taking app in the front.
If you like to travel around, maybe you need your mapsÂ app.

You can decide that for yourself.Â ;)

Third Step
If you canâ€™t control your playing time when playing games. DeleteÂ them.

Youâ€™re crazy.

Did you call me crazy twiceÂ already?

Man, if you like to play games but you canâ€™t control your playtime. Then your phone usage time will stay theÂ same.

But, but, if you are confident that you can control yourself then itâ€™s up to you to delete it orÂ not.

Last Step
Last but not least, Turn Off Your Phone Notification
If itâ€™s not relevant to you to be reached quickly, then turn itÂ off.

Notification can be so distracting atÂ times.

Conclusion:

So yeah, thatâ€™s it. Steps to becoming more productive!
(Well, if you reduce your phone usage time and then you just stare into the blank space, I donâ€™t think you can call that productive though..)

I applied these steps on my phone. And you know what, I reduced my phone usage time from 6 hours daily to only 2 hoursÂ daily.

Iâ€™m still trying to not on my phone so much though. But I think Itâ€™s good enoughÂ already.

Keep your phone down when you are socializing.

items.title: How Minimalism can help you live a Better Life
items.author: William SJ
items.description:
How Minimalism Can Save YourÂ Time

Minimalism is kinda trendy nowadays. But what is minimalism?

Minimalism is essentially living with less, which means you own fewer items. But that doesnâ€™t mean the fewer items you have, you became the most â€œminimalistâ€ person onÂ earth.

You only possess items that give values to your life, so that doesnâ€™t mean if you like to play guitar but because of this so-called minimalism, you started to ditch the guitar too. (This isÂ wrong!)

Thatâ€™s why minimalism consists of twoÂ parts.

  1. Decluttering
  2. Organizing

Letâ€™s talk about decluttering.

Cluttered space will create a cluttered mind. So, start by decluttering things you donâ€™t useÂ anymore.

Like what Marie Kondo said, donâ€™t keep things that do not spark joy inÂ you.

This also applies to the digital world.
Delete your unused apps.
Turn off your notifications.
Keep your digital workspace clean andÂ minimal.

Then Organizing.

After you decluttered your items, then you start by organizing them by categories, like books, clothes, etc.. (or you have your own organizing techniques, itâ€™s up toÂ you)

If you followed these steps,
Tadaâ€¦ you will have much cleaner and minimal space to liveÂ in.

Take in what you cherish, leave out the unneeded.
